MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate - Purchase of Helicopters

Speaker.P: For many years past, organisations and members of the public have sought to have established in this country a helicopter service for relief and rescue and other types of work. On numerous occasions in the House, Deputies have pleaded with the Government to establish such a service. Deputies from all sides have joined in and forgotten Party politics in the hope that their united efforts would be sufficient to force the Government in power to accede to a most reasonable request.

I do not think it is necessary to give many examples of the excellent work done by helicopters in other countries in rescue and relief and fishery protection. I have asked a number of questions here over the past two or three years, in the hope that by constantly urging the Ministers concerned, at some stage there would be a decision to purchase helicopters. To-day I repeated the question I have already asked on a number of occasions and, whatever about replies received in the past, to-day's reply will undobtedly shock and disappoint those who had hoped that by now we could afford a helicopter service, for use particularly along the west coast. The reply given by the Par. Sec. to-day was that the provision of helicopters is kept under review by his Department and other Departments concerned, but he could give no indication of an early decision to provide helicopters. That is the kernel of his reply.

The most important and significant thing about the reply, I think, is that he has sought, in the course of it, to suggest that it would take at least six helicopters to ensure that as far as possible a helicopter would be available within a reasonable time on the occasion of any disaster in the vicinity of our coastline. He has sought to suggest two points by that statement: one, that the sole use of the helicopter would be for rescue work along the coast; and two, that it would take—in order to achieve any success in that field—at least six helicopters. I say that the Par. Sec. and his advisers are deliberately trying to mislead the general public on this very important issue.

MainHeading.P: The facts are that a committee examined the question of using helicopters generally, and I use the word “generally” to include their use for rescue work on the coastline and as an ambulance service to help to bring urgent cases from the islands off the coast to hospital, to help, for instance, to bring maternity cases from outlying islands to hospital on the mainland rather than have expectant mothers undergoing that horrifying and, at times, terrifying journey by lifeboat as they have had to do for years back. That is a use to which helicopters could be put but in regard to which the Minister made no reply. He did not even acknowledge it in his reply to my question, but he sought to suggest that the sole purpose of helicopters, so far as the question was concerned, was to save peoples' lives in the case of disaster at sea.

I think the Par. Sec. showed contempt for the members of the House by giving such a reply. I made it quite clear in the wording of the question that the usefulness of helicopters could extend to fisheries, that a helicopter or two, or three, could be of inestimable value to our fishery protection craft in spotting foreign fleets and foreign vessels when, or if, they were likely to break the three mile limit. It is admitted that helicopters would be of tremendous advantage for such a purpose. It is admitted that they are a most useful means of carrying out hydrographic surveys and ordnance surveys and both are an essential type of work that could be undertaken here and should have been undertaken before this.

These are only some of the uses to which helicopters can be put and when those points were included in the question to-day, the Par. Sec. deliberately ignored them and concentrated on suggesting that I wanted a helicopter service established just for rescue work along the coast. Let us deal with that alone, if the Par. Sec. wants that. Other Deputies raised the question of a helicopter service for that specific purpose and early in 1957, strong pressure was brought to bear in this House to have a helicopter service established on the west coast. Some Deputies wanted it in Donegal to serve the entire west coast from Donegal to Kerry down to Cork. The Government refused to establish the helicopter service.

We all remember that in October of that year, 1957, the country was stunned to hear of the tragedy off the west coast, the terrible tragedy in Clew Bay where five people lost their lives. These people left Clare Island on Tuesday in a currach and set out for the Mayo mainland which they never reached. A search was undertaken for those people by the Kilronan lifeboat on Wednesday. On Thursday, two days after they left the island, Baldonnel sent down a plane to search along the coastline. That plane was not there 40 minutes searching along the coastline. It could not do anything because conditions were too bad for them to stay longer. It is the considered opinion of people who know the situation along the west coast that at least two of the unfortunate people who were lost would have been saved if a helicopter service had been based on the west coast. That is the general impression of people who know.

If it is suggested at this stage that we must depend for rescue work of that nature on the helicopter service based in Eglinton station in Derry, I believe it is wrong to take that view. We must thank the British authorities for their co-operation and assistance every time it has been sought for rescue and relief work on the west coast. Every time a call was made on the British helicopter station in Eglinton, they responded generously with help in rescue and relief work right down along the coast. It is beyond denial that by their early intervention and help they have saved numerous lives during the past five or six years.

It would appear, therefore, that, up to the moment, we have been depending on a helicopter service based on Derry to help us in rescue and relief work right down the coast as far as Cork. That is deplorable, especially in a country like this which claims to have sovereignty and claims to be one of the leading influences in the world, so far as independence is concerned.

That is one instance where it is quite possible lives could have been saved. Some of the Minister's experts may now say that that could not happen. That is only their view as against the views of people who are on the spot and living along the coast line. I challenge contradiction of that.
Let us take the question of the relief work. I quote now from a cutting from the Irish Press headed: “Lighthouse Keepers Stormbound off Mayo.”:—

“A bid to relieve the Eagle Rock Lighthouse, 14 miles off the Mayo Coast, failed yesterday when mountainous seas prevented the relief boat, St. Mary, in Scotchtown harbour from going to the aid of the three keepers who are overdue relief... Rough seas during the last three weeks have made relief impossible.”
I have another cutting from the Irish Press of 11th December, 1926, and I quote:—

“Tory Island (population 300) still had no mail yesterday. Because of heavy seas it is more than three weeks since the mail boat—which usually makes three sailings a week —has been able to reach the island.”
There were 300 people on that island for three weeks in such conditions.

I could go on instancing such cases all round the coast, so far as rescue and relief work are concerned, and yet the Government say the cost is too high. The cost is the key to the whole question—the cost is too much. When the question of cost arises, we should examine our consciences because this country has always been anxious for what is known as prestige. For the purpose of prestige, we are prepared to spend, and have spent, over £1 million for three jet aircraft and the servicing of them. We were told that one of the reasons for the purchase of these jets was to ensure that Irish pilots would be trained in the flying of these planes and that the pilots might, at a later stage, be employed in civil aviation, perhaps in Aer Lingus.

I think we could buy three suitable helicopters for less than £100,000 and those three helicopters would be of inestimable value for the purposes I have mentioned. Remember, the helicopter is the first aircraft that has ever saved more lives than it has taken, and we should be privileged to have these helicopters rather than the jet planes in Baldonnel whose aim is the taking of life.

I should like the Par. Sec. to clarify the following matter which needs clarification. In answer to my question, he said that it would take six helicopters to do the work to which he referred in the earlier part of the answer. In reply to a supplementary question, he said that was the recommendation of a committee which had examined the matter. That committee, I presume, was composed of experts from the various Departments concerned. I should like him to explain how it is that when the Minister for Defence was asked about this very problem on 27th March, 1958, he stated in the House:—
The range of these craft is extremely limited and one helicopter would be absolutely no use. It would be purely a matter of coincidence if it happened to be in the right spot at the right time.
—This is the important part—
It is estimated that the very minimum that would be of any practical use would be three.

Speaker.P: What is the reference?

Col. 1209, vol. 166, of the Official Report. The Minister had been queried by me six months prior to that and he was queried by Deputy Blowick a week before that. He was not replying for the Department of Defence alone but on behalf of every other Department which had considered this problem. In reply to the question, he mentioned rescue services along the coast, and his argument was that it would take three helicopters to do the work. The reason I asked in my question: if the Minister would consider purchasing two such aircraft was that I felt that three were necessary. Originally, I thought one would be useful but I came around to the Government's view that one would not be sufficient and so I asked them to purchase two and the answer I got was the astounding revelation that six would be needed.

MainHeading.P: Who is advising the Department? What kind of experts sit down and advise the Minister for Defence that it will take three aircraft and who are the experts who advise the Par. Sec. to-day that it will take six? Does not that show that no thought whatever has been given to this problem for the past 12 months, and that the Par. Sec. and the Government have nothing but contempt for Deputies who dare to ask questions on such problems, when they are not even prepared to give consideration to them?

I would ask the Par. Sec. to reconsider this matter, and if he suggests that it would cost too much, I would ask him to consult with his Minister for Finance who told us yesterday and to-day that he is prepared to hand back the sum of £25,000 to dance-hall proprietors for the rock-'n'-roll merchants.

Speaker.P: That does not arise.

It does arise, since the Minister thinks it is more advisable to give £25,000 back to the rock-'n'-roll dance-hall proprietors. He also thinks it is more advisable to hand back, as he did, £20,000 to the dog-track owners.
The Deputy may not make a speech in relation to the Financial Resolutions on the Motion for the Adjournment.
I do not intend to, Sir.
The Par. Sec. is allowed 10 minutes in which to reply.
I started speaking at two minutes past five.
According to my record the Deputy began to speak at one minute past five.

In conclusion, I would prefer the Par. Sec. at this stage to say whether he is prepared to reconsider the position in view of the benefits that would be conferred on the public generally and particularly on the people in the West of Ireland. If three helicopters, were purchased they could be based at Limerick or anywhere that was thought suitable. I do not mind where they are placed. My argument is not on the basis of selecting any particular locality. Let the experts decide about that.

Speaker.hpid: Par. Sec. to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Hilliard) Par. Sec. to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Hilliard)
Speaker.NameTxt: Par. Sec. to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Hilliard)
Speaker.P: Deputy McQuillan seems to take umbrage at the fact that he was told today by me that the minimum number of helicopters required for any operation was six. He seems to think that because some time previously the Minister for Defence said the very minimum should be three, there is some conflict of opinion between the various Departments as to what exactly would be required for a helicopter service to be of use.

What use should be made of a helicopter service is all a matter of opinion. When one is answering a question of this kind one has to decide in one's own mind what exactly the service can be used for. If a service were to be provided to meet all the eventualities enumerated by the Deputy in his speech, it would take a large number of helicopters to be of effective use, if they would be of any effective use. Deputy McQuillan referred to the taking of maternity cases off the islands around our coasts. Previously he asked questions in regard to the relief of storm-bound islands. He also had in mind apparently the use of helicopters for commercial and other purposes. The Minister for Defence, of course, was replying to a specific question in regard to the use of helicopters in a military sense and in his reply broadened out to refer to their use in a general way.

A committee of representatives of various Departments have made certain recommendations and have advised the Minister that six helicopters would be required as a bare minimum. You would also have to provide maintenance for the helicopters and a staff of persons to provide the service. Then it would be problematical whether or not all these helicopters could be used in the type of sea rescue work that would arise around our coasts in bad weather. Deputy McQuillan mentioned their use in the event of an island being stormbound for a certain length of time, but if there were very high winds on that occasion a helicopter might not be of any use.
I am afraid the Par. Sec. is not up-to-date.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The Deputy got his chance; he should allow the Par. Sec. to reply.

We are as up-to-date as the Deputy. I do not purport to have technical knowledge on the use of helicopters but every Minister charged with responsibility to this House and to the country must take the advice of technical persons in relation to the provision of a service such as this or any other service that the State provides. He cannot be influenced by suggestions made by persons who may not have the necessary knowledge to enable him to come to a proper decision on such questions.
Deputy Boland said three helicopters would be sufficient.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The Deputy should allow the Par. Sec. to speak. He did not interrupt the Deputy.

I can speak whether he interrupts or not. Deputy McQuillan seems to think this question is still not being considered. It is being considered and we shall not have to go to the trouble of having the question reconsidered. It has been considered and will continue to be considered until a satisfactory solution has been found. There are other persons interested in the provision of a helicopter service in this country and if their proposals can be fitted in to suit the requirements of the State the matter will be given active consideration, and the State will be prepared, I would say, to make a contribution.

I do not think the Deputy raised any other question which calls for a reply from me. We know the provision of two helicopters would be absolutely useless. I have said six would be essential for a minimum operation and, if we were to consider the provision of a full-scale service such as that advocated by Deputy McQuillan, it would take a good deal more money and it would have to be provided out of sources other than those suggested by the Deputy in his speech.
